Mr. nicemaletrust posts hundreds of messages, but they get stopped before t=
hey hit the list, he gets deleted and he rejoins under a new but similar us=
er name.  I've come to admire "his" persistence, although he's probably a b=
oiler room somewhere rather than an individual.

I'm afraid that Gordon may=
 be waving his cane and yelling at the kids to stay off his lawn before lon=
g...

I had a chance to look at a very interesting tsuba recently.  It's a =
typical bird in the plum tree Higo guard, but what's interesting is that it=
 wasn't completed.  The design is scribed into the plate and all of the rou=
ghing out was done with a chisel.  Even the outline of the rim is chiseled =
in with multiple cuts from both sides. It looks like a slight gouge was use=
d while cutting the rim and most of the sukashi was cut with a straight chi=
sel.

A couple of sections of sukashi have some file work done, but the res=
t is still rough.  It looks like one of the thin branches was chiseled down=
 too thin to be finished properly and the piece was abandoned.  The color o=
f the guard isn't bad (even though I doubt any patina was applied) and the =
build up on the interior sukashi walls looks about like you'd expect for an=
 Edo piece.

I recently spent two weeks shooting in Baja Sur, Mexico.  A gr=
eat place, other than the developed Cabo area on the southern tip. 

A few =
wildlife photos from both the Pacific and Gulf sides:

http://www.flickr.co=
m/photos/jggilbert/sets/72157623839030000/

Jim

www.jimgilbertphoto.com
